statement.text: Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm is a vascular emergency with 80-90% overall mortality. The classic triad of abdominal/back pain, hypotension, and pulsatile abdominal mass is present in only ~50% of cases. Most ruptures are posterior into the retroperitoneum, which may provide temporary tamponade. Immediate surgical repair (open or EVAR) is the only life-saving intervention.
statement.formal: Ruptured AAA: Classic Triad (50%): Abdominal/back pain + Hypotension + Pulsatile mass | Mortality: 50% prehospital, 80-90% overall | Treatment: Emergency OR (open repair or EVAR if hemodynamically stable)

explanation.intuition: When an aortic aneurysm ruptures, blood escapes under high pressure into the surrounding space. If it ruptures forward into the abdominal cavity (free rupture), death occurs within minutes from massive hemorrhage. More commonly, it ruptures backward into the retroperitoneum, where the tissues temporarily contain the bleeding like a pressure bandage. This 'contained rupture' gives a window for rescue, but it's brief - the tamponade will fail.
explanation.key_insight: Speed is everything in ruptured AAA. Half of patients die before reaching the hospital. Of those who make it, every hour of delay increases mortality. The mantra is 'diagnose fast, operate faster.' A hemodynamically unstable patient with known or suspected AAA goes directly to the operating room - CT is only for stable patients where diagnosis is uncertain.
explanation.technical_details: Rupture patterns: (1) Posterior/retroperitoneal (80%) - may be temporarily contained; (2) Anterior/intraperitoneal (20%) - rapidly fatal free rupture; (3) Aortocaval fistula (<5%) - high-output cardiac failure; (4) Aortoenteric fistula (rare) - GI hemorrhage. Hemodynamic instability with suspected rupture should trigger 'massive transfusion protocol.' Permissive hypotension (SBP 70-90 mmHg) may help avoid disrupting retroperitoneal tamponade. EVAR for rupture (rEVAR) has emerged as an option for hemodynamically stable patients with suitable anatomy, with potential mortality benefit.
common_misconceptions: All ruptured AAAs have the classic triad - only ~50% do
CT is required before surgery - not in unstable patients
Open repair is always needed - rEVAR is an option for stable patients
Survival is hopeless - operative survival is 50-60% if patient reaches OR

definitions_glossary.contained_rupture: Rupture where blood is temporarily held by retroperitoneal tissues
definitions_glossary.free_rupture: Rupture into peritoneal cavity with uncontained hemorrhage
definitions_glossary.retroperitoneum: Space behind the abdominal cavity containing the aorta
definitions_glossary.permissive_hypotension: Allowing lower BP to avoid disrupting hemostatic clot
definitions_glossary.massive_transfusion_protocol: Protocol for rapid blood product administration in hemorrhage

other_presentations: Grey Turner sign (flank ecchymosis - late sign)

retroperitoneal.prognosis: May be temporarily contained, better survival chance

aortocaval_fistula.presentation: High-output heart failure, leg swelling, machinery murmur

management_algorithm: Suspect rupture in any elderly patient with abdominal/back pain + hypotension
If unstable: Direct to OR, no CT needed
If stable: Rapid CT to confirm diagnosis and assess EVAR suitability
Emergency repair: Open or EVAR depending on stability and anatomy

definition.@value: Life-threatening vascular emergency from AAA wall failure with hemorrhage

sources.citation: Reimerink JJ, et al. Systematic review and meta-analysis of population-based mortality from ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Br J Surg. 2013;100(11):1405-1413.

learning_objectives: Recognize the clinical presentation of ruptured AAA
Understand the pathophysiology of contained vs free rupture
Apply permissive hypotension in hemorrhagic shock
Determine when CT is appropriate vs immediate OR
clinical_pearls: If in doubt about rupture and patient is unstable = go to OR
Classic triad is only 50% sensitive - don't rely on it
Contained rupture = window of opportunity, but don't waste it
rEVAR may be better than open for stable patients
